Could not find a description of this building

Architecture Building (AA)

The Architecture Building was designed specifically for Carleton’s architecture program with its large open studio spaces, flexible classrooms, and fully-equipped work stations. Studios are open 24-hours-a-day.

Try the carpentry workshop for the construction of models and prototypes. A consulting firm run by some of the school’s best students offers Ottawa-area homeowners architectural and design services at bargain prices.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the Architecture Building

!-- START CONTENT -->

Azrieli Pavilion

The new David J. Azrieli Pavilion is located next to the Tory Building and Dunton Tower along Library Road. The 75,000-square-foot pavilion opened in the fall of 2002.

The pavilion will be home to the newly named David Azrieli Institute for Graduate Studies in Architecture, as well as the new Bachelor of Information Technology program (www.bitdegree.ca). The building will also house the new Azrieli Gallery, dedicated to architecture and allied arts, and the National Capital Institute for Telecommunications — a research consortium of facilities across the region, which will explore the latest telecommunications technologies.

Students at the new facility have access to four large lecture halls, specialized computer laboratories and workrooms, and state-of-the-art classrooms, teaching studios and seminar rooms.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for Azrieli Pavilion

Ice House (IH)

The Icehouse is part of Carleton University’s world class athletics facilities. The most comprehensive adult facility of its kind in central Ottawa, the $13 million state-of-the-art ice facility is the cornerstone of the Carleton Athletics Recreation Centre.

The main arena seats 500 spectators while the secondary rink accommodates 100 viewers. Operational year-round, the Icehouse features 2 NHL-sized ice surfaces with six dressing rooms per ice pad.

Icehouse details

  • Icehouse Website
  • 2 NHL-sized ice surfaces
  • Year-round access (open 12 months a year)
  • 500 spectator capacity in the main arena
  • 100 spectator capacity in the second arena
  • Exceptional ice conditions
  • Six dressing rooms per ice pad
  • Michael Lawrence Pro Goaltending
  • Lightning Blade Sharpening

Carleton Technology and Training Centre

The Carleton Technology and Training Centre is home to the University’s Health Services, Parking Services, the Co-op Office, Environmental Health and Safety, pharmacy, dental clinic, “Treats”, and a variety of Ottawa-based companies and associations.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the Carleton Technology and Training Centre.

Colonel By Child Care Centre (CC)

The Colonel By Child Care Centre accepts children between the ages of six months and five years.

Priority is given to students, staff, and faculty. The Centre’s staff provide programming for infants, toddlers, and preschoolers along with hot lunches and snacks.

The Centre is opened 12 months a year, Monday to Friday between 8:00 a.m. and 5:45 p.m. except on statutory holidays.

General enquiries: 613-520-2715

Dunton Tower (DT)

The 22-storey tower houses various schools, institutes, departments, and research centres. The Dunton Tower honours the memory of Carleton’s longest serving president A. Davidson Dunton, who led the university from 1958 to 1972. During his long and distinguished career chaired the CBC and co-chaired the Royal Commission on Bilingualism and Biculturalism.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the Dunton Tower.

Fieldhouse (Athletics)

The Fieldhouse is located north of the main Recreation building in the Department of Athletics and Recreation. The Fieldhouse is a popular spot for Carleton students who are keen on staying in shape, and for residents in neighbouring communities as well.

Features:

  • 4,500 square metre sports field – Artificial turf (Rec-Turf 2)
  • 230 metre, 3 lane jogging track – Rubber base with a poured urethane finish
  • Inside lane – 4.3 laps to the km/Outside Lane – 4.26 laps to the km
  • Full length field – approx. 65 metres long (213 feet) x 53 metres wide (173 feet)
  • Two cross fields: each approx. 53 metres long (173 feet) x 26 metres wide (87 feet)
  • Year-round access
  • The ability to host indoor trade shows, concerts, job fairs and community events

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for Fieldhouse (Athletics)

Glengarry House

Designated Parking

Eight designated parking spaces are available on the east side of Stormont- Dundas House, near Para Transpo drop-off area.

Exterior Entrance

Accessible ramp on west side.

Tunnel Access

Accessible tunnel entrance to level 1 with automatic door openers.

Elevators

Two fully accessible elevators with horizontal control panels.

Washrooms

No public washrooms in this building. Washrooms in the designated accessible suites on levels 1 and 2 are accessible.

Telephones

Accessible pay phones on the first level.

Lecture/Classroom areas

Not applicable.

Study Areas

Not applicable.

Proximity to Lounges/Refreshments

Residence floors have TV lounges which are often crowded. Close to Oasis Cafeteria and to University Commons dining hall.

Existing/Remaining Obstacles

  1. Heavy glass doors at exterior west entrance.
  2. Need for alternate emergency system for persons with hearing impairments.
  3. Need for better signage system.

Remarks/Hints

Access into the building is regulated by security card access system which is accessible to wheelchair users. This may eliminate the problem of heavy doors but creates other access problems.

Compiled by the Paul Menton Centre for Persons with Disabilities.

Grenville (GR) and Russell House (RU)

Designated parking

One designated parking space at the back of Russell House. Additional spaces are available at Stormont-Dundas.

Exterior Entrance

Accessible main entrances at ground level.

Tunnel Access

Accessible tunnel entrance directly across from tunnel entrance to the Commons Building and Glengarry House.

Elevators

One useable elevator; dimensions not sufficient to accommodate a large wheelchair, some control buttons may be difficult to reach for some wheelchair users.

Washrooms

Inaccessible public washrooms. Private washrooms in the designated accessible suites should be accessible.

Telephones

Accessible phones in the lobby of Russell House and Grenville House.

Lecture/Classroom Areas

Not applicable.

Study Areas

Not applicable.

Proximity to Lounges/Refreshments

Residence floors have large accessible TV lounges. Close to all cafeteria/ lounge facilities in the Commons.

Existing/Remaining Obstacles

Elevator not very accessible; heavy doors with high handles at tunnel entrance; need an automatic door opener; Rooms 165 A and B (one of the designated accessible suites) still have minor access problems.

Remarks/Hints

A two-bedroom suite has been renovated to accommodate students with disabilities in each of these two residences.

Compiled by the Paul Menton Centre for Persons with Disabilities.

Herzberg Laboratories (HP)

The Herzberg Laboratories for Physics and Computer Science was named for Gerhard Herzberg, Canada’s first Nobel Prize recipient for natural sciences, and Carleton’s former Chancellor.

The building houses the School of Computer Science, the School of Mathematics and Statistics, the Department of Physics, Department of Earth Sciences (including their $10 million POLARIS project), the Environmental Science program, Integrated Science program, and the Faculty of Science Dean’s Office.

A roof-top observatory features a powerful star-gazing 14″ reflecting Celestron telescope.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the Herzberg Laboratories.

Lanark House (LH)

Designated Parking

Closest is located on the east side of Stormont-Dundas House (eight spaces), Campus Avenue.

Exterior Entrance

Ground level access only.

Tunnel Access

No tunnel access to this building.

Elevators

None.

Washrooms

Not accessible.

Telephones

Lowered phones on the first level are accessible to wheelchair users.

Lecture/Classroom Areas

Not applicable.

Study Areas

Not applicable.

Proximity to Lounges/Refreshments

Residence floors have their own lounges. Closest to Oasis Cafeteria on first level of the Commons.

Existing/Remaining Obstacles

No elevator; no accessible washrooms; no tunnel access.

Remarks/Hints

Lanark House is generally inaccessible to persons with mobility impairments. It has numerous access problems requiring major and costly renovations. This is not a major concern since there are already accessible units in Glengary House, Russell House, Grenville House, and Stormont-Dundas House.

Compiled by the Paul Menton Centre for Persons with Disabilities.

Life Sciences Research Building

The Life Sciences Research Building is a specialized laboratory which supports experimental work in the biological, biochemical, and behavioural sciences.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the Life Sciences Research Building.

The Loeb Building (LA)

The Loeb Building recognizes the financial contributions made to Carleton by Ottawa’s Loeb family. It houses offices for the Faculty of Public Affairs, as well as various academic departments, a cafeteria and lounge, classrooms and laboratories.

It is also home to the University’s Music department with its extensive collection of musical instruments, scores and periodicals.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the Loeb Building.

The Mackenzie Engineering Building (ME)

The Mackenzie Building honours Chalmers Jack Mackenzie who was Carleton’s second chancellor, president of the National Research Council, first president of Atomic Energy of Canada Limited and instrumental in the development of science and engineering education in Canada.

The building contains facilities to support all engineering disciplines. It’s also home to Carleton’s industrial design program.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the Mackenzie Building.

MacOdrum Library

The MacOdrum Library, named in honour of Carleton’s second president Murdoch Maxwell MacOdrum, contains a collection of more than two million items—books, microfilms, tapes, CDs, government documents, maps, periodicals and archival materials—as well as study space, reading rooms and café.

A computerized catalogue system provides access to the collection.

Related links

  • Access Services
    http://www.library.carleton.ca/
  • Acquisitions

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the MacOdrum Library.

The Minto Centre

The Minto Centre for Advanced Studies in Engineering, located off the east wing of the Mackenzie Building, houses state-of-the-art facilities for research and studies in engineering, including a flight-simulating wind tunnel. A 400-seat lecture theatre offers the latest in audio-visual equipment. The building is named in honour of Minto Developments Inc., an Ottawa-based real estate development firm.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the Minto Centre.

Nesbitt Building (NB)

H. H. J. Nesbitt Biology Building

Formerly known as the Environmental Laboratories (ELBA)

Designated Parking

Closest parking for persons with disabilities is in the Parking Garage (five spaces) and Lot 3 (four spaces). There is also plenty of non-designated, spacious, pay and display spots nearby on University Drive.

Exterior Entrance

Avoid the side entrance at the corner of Raven Road and University Drive, the main entrance is at the south side of the building.
There are curb cuts at the corner of Raven Road and University Drive.

Exterior Areas

Picnic area to the south of building is easily accessible from the walkway that runs long University Drive.

Tunnel Access

Accessible at basement level to passenger elevator.

Elevators

Refurbished, accessible passenger elevator to all levels

Washrooms

Washrooms are fully accessible. Main level washrooms have automatic door operators.

Telephones

There are no public telephones

Lecture/Classroom Areas

Not applicable.

Study Areas

Small, pleasant lounge/study area at front entrance accessible from Monday to Friday 8:30 am to 4:30 pm

Proximity to Lounges/Refreshments

Free standing tables and chairs near main entrance for lounging or studying.

Two display greenhouses on Main level, both are accessible. Smaller greenhouse has one narrow pathway near the back, but is navigable. Both greenhouses have some tight turns, but are accessible.

Existing/Remaining Obstacles

No significant barriers

Remarks/Hints

For individuals with mobility impairments, greenhouses may be easier to navigate in a manual wheelchair, but electric wheelchairs can access both greenhouses.

Compiled by the Paul Menton Centre for Persons with Disabilities.

National Wildlife Research Centre

The National Wildlife Research Centre occupies new facilities on the Carleton University campus in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada. This location opens the door to new partnerships, giving government and university scientists new opportunities to collaborate on science that is critical to wildlife conservation.

The modern research centre has approximately 5700 m² of floor space and includes:

  • Laboratories
    15 well-equipped laboratories to support the monitoring and research activities of the Wildlife Toxicology Division and to accommodate students and researchers.

  • Greenhouse
    A 100 m² greenhouse and plant growth chambers for studies requiring controlled environmental conditions.
  • Specimen bank
    Wildlife specimen storage facilities with three walk-in freezer rooms
    (-40°C), four ultra-low temperature (-80°C) chest freezers, and four liquid nitrogen storage tanks (about -150°C in the vapour phase).

Paterson Hall

Paterson Hall is named after Norman Paterson, one of Canada’s longest serving senators whose generous financial support helped to develop Carleton’s world-renowned programs in international affairs.

Here you’ll find the College of Humanities, the Department of History, the Department of Philosophy, the Institute for African Studies, the CAEL Office and the School of Linguistics and Language Studies.

A branch of the Bank of Nova Scotia is located on the lower level.

Accessibility Guide Listing for Paterson Hall.

Renfrew House (RH)

Designated parking

Closest is in front of Stormont-Dundas House.

Exterior Entrance

Level 1 access only from entrances off Library Road.

Tunnel Access

No tunnel access.

Elevators

No elevator.

Washrooms

Inaccessible

Telephones

Accessible phones on first level.

Lecture/Classroom Areas

Not applicable.

Study Areas

Not applicable.

Proximity to Lounges/Refreshments

Residence floors have their own lounges. Close to all cafeteria/lounge facilities in the University Commons Building.

Existing/Remaining Obstacles

Need for an accessible graduate residence.

Remarks/Hints

Renfrew House is the designated graduate student residence. It is completely inaccessible to wheelchair users.

Compiled by the Paul Menton Centre for Persons with Disabilities.

Residence Commons (RC)

Designated parking

In front of Stormont-Dundas House (six spaces).

Exterior Entrance

West side entrance via ramp. Automatic door.

Tunnel Access

Tunnel entrance to level 1 equipped with an automatic door opener.

Elevators

An accessible elevator designated for the exclusive use of persons with disabilities.

Washrooms

Accessible public washrooms located outside the PMC office.

Telephones

Pay phones on levels 1 and 2 are accessible.

Lecture/Classroom Areas

Classrooms are generally accessible.

Study Areas

No study areas. PMC, Counselling and Health Services operate a Student Resource Centre as part of the PMC Satellite Office.

Proximity to Lounges/Refreshments

Vending machines, lounge areas, Oasis Cafeteria, Bree’s Inn, Abstentions Store, and main residence cafeteria/dining hall.

Existing/Remaining Obstacles

Fenn Lounge on level 2 is accessible at the upper level only.

Remarks/Hints

The Office of the Coordinator of the 24-hour Attendant Services Program is located in Room 223.

Compiled by the Paul Menton Centre for Persons with Disabilities.

Robertson Hall (RO)

Robertson Hall is named in honour of former chancellor and chancellor emeritus Gordon Robertson.

It houses the University Archives, Admissions Services, the Undergraduate Recruitment Office, the Business Office, Awards Office, Computing and Communications Services, Human Resources, University Services, Graphic Services, University Communications, Development and Alumni, meeting rooms and offices for the University Senate and Board of Governors.

A wall in the lobby recognizes major contributors to the University’s Challenge Fund Campaign.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for Robertson Hall.

St. Patrick’s Building (SP)

The St. Patrick’s Building once housed St. Patrick’s College, a small liberal arts school which was part of Carleton University from 1967-79. The building is now home to the Institute of Comparative Studies in Literature, Art and Culture (ICSLAC), the School of Journalism and Communication, the School for Studies in Art and Culture, the Carleton University Art Gallery, and the extensive Reader’s Digest Resource Centre.

Occupants

  • Art and Culture, School for Studies in, Room 423
  • Art Gallery, Carleton University
  • Art History, Room 423
  • Art History, Centre for New Work in Canadian, Room 476
  • Audio-Visual Library, Room 460
  • Cinema and Nation, Centre for Studies in, Room 418
  • Film Studies, Room 423B
  • Institute of Comparative Studies in Literature, Art and Culture (ICSLAC), Room 201
  • Journalism and Communication, School of, Room 346
  • Mass Communication, Room 310
  • Reader’s Digest Canada Resource Centre, Room 102
  • Survey Centre, Carleton University, Room 312

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the St. Patrick’s Building.

Social Sciences Research Building (SR)

The Social Sciences Research Building houses research centres that support studies in the social sciences. These include the Centre for Immigration and Ethno-Cultural Studies, the Centre for Labour Studies, and the Laboratory of Sleep and Chronopsychology.

Campus Accessibility listing for Social Sciences Research Building (SR)

Southam Hall

Southam Hall honours Carleton’s first chancellor and former publisher of The Ottawa Citizen Harry Stevenson Southam, who also donated a significant portion of the land on which the campus is built.

Here you will find the 444-seat Kailash Mital Theatre, Carleton’s largest lecture hall. Two fully-equipped television studios on the sixth floor are used by Carleton’s instructional television service (CUTV), which provides distance education courses throughout the Ottawa Valley via digital cable television, and by students in the University’s highly acclaimed journalism program.

The Outdoor Amphitheatre between Southam and Paterson halls is used for concerts and classes during fair weather.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for Southam Hall

Steacie Building (SC)

The Steacie Building for Chemistry is named in honour of E.W.R. Steacie, a distinguished chemist who served as chair of Carleton’s board of governors and president of the National Research Council.

The building houses a lecture theatre, classrooms, labs, and a computer room.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the Steacie Building.

Stormont-Dundas House (SD)

Designated parking

Eight designated parking spaces on east side of the building.

Exterior Entrance

All exterior entrances are accessible at ground level.

Tunnel Access

Accessible tunnel entrance with automatic doors.

Elevators

Two accessible elevators, one in each residence.

Washrooms

No public washroom in this building, but washrooms in the 20 accessible units are fully accessible.

Lecture/Classroom Areas

Not applicable.

Study Areas

TV lounge and study areas on each floor.

Proximity to Lounges/Refreshments

Direct access to main residence cafeteria, Oasis Cafeteria and vending machines in the Commons building.

Compiled by the Paul Menton Centre for Persons with Disabilities.

Tory Building (TB)

The Tory building was the first building on campus. It was named after the first President of Carleton College, Henry Marshall Tory. The building has been renovated three times since Leslie Frost, then premier of Ontario, first laid its corner stone in 1957.

Only the mural in the central lecture hall, commonly known as “The Egg”, has remained unaltered. J. Harold Shenkman, a local entrepreneur, commissioned Gerald Trottier to create the piece. The Ottawa artist wanted the mural to depict humanity’s quest for knowledge.

Campus Accessibility Guide listing for the Tory Building.

University Centre (UC)

Designated parking

Available in Lot 2 (three spaces) and at the loading dock (two spaces). Lot 2 requires a permit to park.

Exterior Entrance

Two accessible entrances:

  1. main front entrance located on the east side of the building, near Parking Lot 2, and
  2. loading dock entrance at level 2 by Porter Hall.

Both have automatic door openers.

Tunnel Access

Tunnel entrances at the first level and on the fourth level from the University Centre-Tory Building link.

Elevators

One accessible elevator services all levels and is equipped with tactile buttons and signs. Does not service one wing of the third floor, which is serviced instead by a wheelchair lift from the second level.

Washrooms

Accessible washrooms located on levels 1, 2, 3, and 5.

Telephones

Pay phones accessible. Designated phones for priority use of persons with disabilities located on levels 2 (lobby of Porter Hall), 4 and 5.

Lecture/Classroom Areas

Porter Hall (level 2) and Baker’s lounge (level 4) are used for occasional events and lectures.

Study Areas

Baker’s lounge on fourth level.

Proximity to Lounges/Refreshments

Hugo’s, Arcade, Unicentre Store and Oliver’s on first level. Peppermill Cafeteria and Mike’s Place on second level. Rooster’s, Faculty Club on the fourth level.

Existing/Remaining Obstacles

More direct access through Porter Hall from the loading dock. No elevator access to one wing of the third floor.

Remarks/Hints

In order to avoid a steep, troublesome rise in the tunnel system as it goes around the University Centre (three stories high), students should use the University Centre-Tory Building link to get to the top of the tunnel rise.

Compiled by the Paul Menton Centre for Persons with Disabilities.
